awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: In Situ Surface Spectroscopy of 2D Material-based Electrocatalysis and Photoelectrocatalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Electrochemical and photoelectrochemical processes are important to a wide range of energy-related and environmental applications, including solar energy storage and carbon remediation. Photoelectrochemical hydrogen production is especially exciting for its potential to convert solar energy into carbon-free chemical fuels. The project will enable increased efficiency of photoelectrocatalytic reactions through study of the fundamental physical and chemical processes occurring in a class of ultrathin catalytic materials important for the sustainable production of fuels and chemicals.

The study will investigate electrocatalysis (EC) and photoeletrocatalysis (PEC) in two-dimensional dichalcogenide materials using various forms of in situ linear, nonlinear, and ultrafast spectroscopy to characterize three critical factors in EC/PEC reactions: interfacial electrostatics (local (i.e., surface) electrostatic fields), interfacial dynamics and electrostatics (photoexcited charge carrier dynamics), and interfacial molecular structures (surface bound intermediate species) produced during the EC and PEC processes. Sum frequency generation (SFG), second harmonic generation (SHG), vibrational Stark Shift (VSS) spectroscopy, and transient absorption spectroscopy (TAS) will be employed to reveal key mechanistic information regarding the EC and PEC processes primarily for the reduction of CO2 to methanol and carbon monoxide.  Spectroscopic data will be acquired in situ as a function of the electrochemical potential and electrolyte composition, and correlated with product yield and selectivity.  The project includes educational and outreach activities that build upon the research to promote engagement of students in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. These activities, which include workshop for high school science teachers, are directed at improving the education of promising high school students and encouraging their interest in STEM careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this work, researchers developed and refined vibrational sum frequency generation (VSFG) spectroscopy methods to directly probe molecular events at electrocatalytic interfaces. By implementing a total internal reflection (TIR) design, they minimized mass transport limitations and IR absorption losses, enabling the observation of transient, strongly IR-absorbing species that arise during CO2 electroreduction on metal surfaces. The development of a custom electrochemical cell allowed simultaneous VSFG and electrochemical measurements, ensuring realistic conditions and reducing depletion effects.

 

Using this setup, the team examined cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), a surfactant often used to control side reactions like the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). The in-situ VSFG approach provided orientation and conformation information on CTAB under both positive and negative potentials. Notably, the terminal methyl group displayed distinct symmetric and asymmetric vibrational signals, allowing researchers to deduce surfactant tilt angles and better understand how CTAB may influence electron transfer processes.

 

A further advance was the development of transient electric-field-induced VSFG (EFI-VSFG) spectroscopy, which measures how transient electric fields, generated by ultrafast interfacial charge transfer, alter the VSFG response. By tracking both the vibrational signatures and the transient DC field, the method clarifies how molecular conformation changes affect charge movement at interfaces. This was demonstrated in a model system of two organic semiconductors, where the team confirmed ground-state charge transfer in real time.

 

To explore advanced materials for electrochemical or photoelectrochemical applications, the researchers also prepared monolayer MoS2 and WS2, confirming their single-layer character via photoluminescence and Raman spectroscopy. By integrating an optical microscope with the SFG system, they could pinpoint these atomically thin regions and study their interfacial properties in detail. The team envisions using such 2D materials to investigate how nanometer-scale thickness and large surface area might enhance charge transfer and catalytic processes.

 

Altogether, this body of work shows that combining TIR-VSFG, EFI-VSFG, and specialized electrochemical cells provides a powerful toolkit for revealing how molecular orientations, transient fields, and charge transfer events govern electrocatalysis. These insights are expected to guide the design of next-generation materials and devices for energy-related applications, from CO2 reduction to solar-driven catalysis.
